title: Baked Ziti Recipe
description: Baked ziti pasta with ground beef, spaghetti sauce, and three kinds of Italian cheese makes a surprisingly easy, family-pleasing weeknight meal.
body: ​ Skip to content Allrecipes Search Please fill out this field. Search the site Please fill out this field. About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Main Dishes Pasta Baked Ziti 4.7 (8,904) 6,296 Reviews 780 Photos This baked ziti is always a hit! A lady I worked with brought this in one day, and everyone loved it. Now it is the favorite of all my dinner guests. I have made this also without the meat, and it is well received. Submitted by Colleen Updated on October 3, 2024 Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen The Allrecipes Test Kitchen staff are a team of culinary pros who make and vet recipes using only equipment you'd find in a home kitchen. Staff credentials vary but include training at the Culinary Institute of America; kitchen stints in fine dining restaurants; and countless hours in the test kitchen itself. Meet the Allrecipes Test Kitchen Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 780 780 780 780 Prep Time: 15 mins Cook Time: 45 mins Total Time: 1 hr Servings: 10 Yield: 1 9x13-inch casserole Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 10 servings 1 pound dry ziti pasta 1 onion, chopped 1 pound lean ground beef 2 (26 ounce) jars spaghetti sauce 6 ounces provolone cheese, sliced 1 ½ cups sour cream 6 ounces mozzarella cheese, shredded 2 tablespoons grated Parmesan cheese Directions Gather all ingredients. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Add ziti pasta, and cook until al dente, about 8 minutes; drain. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Meanwhile, brown ground beef and onion in a large skillet over medium heat; stir in spaghetti sauce and simmer for 15 minutes. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Butter a 9x13-inch baking dish. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Spread 1/2 of the ziti in the bottom of the prepared dish. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Top with Provolone cheese. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Top with sour cream. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Add 1/2 of the meat sauce, remaining ziti, mozzarella cheese, and remaining meat sauce. Top with grated Parmesan cheese. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Bake in the preheated oven until heated through and cheeses have melted, about 30 minutes. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios I Made It Print 12,633 home cooks made it! Nutrition Facts (per serving) 578 Calories 25g Fat 58g Carbs 28g Protein Show Full Nutrition Label Hide Full Nutrition Label Nutrition Facts Servings Per Recipe 10 Calories 578 % Daily Value * Total Fat 25g 32% Saturated Fat 13g 64% Cholesterol 71mg 24% Sodium 914mg 40% Total Carbohydrate 58g 21% Dietary Fiber 6g 21% Total Sugars 14g Protein 28g 56% Vitamin C 4mg 4% Calcium 359mg 28% Iron 4mg 19% Potassium 721mg 15% * Percent Daily Values are based on a 2,000 calorie diet. Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. (-) Information is not currently available for this nutrient. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of Baked Ziti 01 of 780 Photo by  Dotdash Meredith Food Studios 02 of 780 Photo by  UncleHanale 04/04/2025 Easy to follow I used penne pasta as a substitute for ziti pasta, because it sticks to the sauce better. Also, I replaced sour cream for ricotta cheese for a more richer flavor. 03 of 780 Photo by  Daryl 03/01/2025 This was super easy to make. I used gluten free penne in place of the ziti. I baked it for 30 minutes and it came out perfect and tasted wonderful. I reviewed it on my YouTube channel, The Real Deal Recipe Reviews, where I always try to make recipes as written and give honest reviews and opinions. If you're looking for an easy baked ziti that feeds several people, this is it! 04 of 780 Photo by  Angie Lindsey 10/01/2024 I took the suggestion to mix the ziti with the sauce!! Simple, easy and delicious!!! 05 of 780 Photo by  SpeedyScoop6059 09/28/2024 Well, I’m home by myself for a week as my wife is taking care of the grandchildren in Kentucky. No problem I can cook and one of my favorites is baked ziti! I need a recipe for everything I cook to keep me honest and on task so I found this one to be a lot of fun. I ran out of my own homemade sauce with sweet Italian sausage and had too much ricotta and sour cream. Excuse me, I didn’t tell you that I mixed a bag of grated Parmesan cheese with the ricotta and sour cream. I was terrified that I made a mistake in the recipe and I’d never be able to eat again, but it turned out great! The mixup really didn’t matter and of course there was no one here to criticize me so I got off the hook. The dishes came out to be the best. I started with a 9 x 9 and ended up with two 9 x 9 in Pyrex , I did cover them with aluminum foil to save the moisture. The second batch was made with a Vodka sauce, and turned out to be fabulous.Italian food is wonderful as you know and there would be no happiness without it as John Goodman noted. I guess I’m saying that you can’t screw up Italian food by mixing up different kinds of grated cheese. I have fresh basil in my garden and added five or six leaves to each of the 9 x 9 ‘s. I also added a sprig from the top of the bush as garnish. Yes, it did dry out, but tasted fabulous with the mouthful of vodka sauce and more cheese. I found a provolone-mozzarella shredded mix in a bag so I sprinkled this on the vodka dish. I’ve enjoyed both dishes for several days and hope to repeat the vodka sauce, ziti for my wife when and if she comes home. Thanks for the recipe. 06 of 780 Photo by  Alana 07/09/2024 A keeper! Easy to follow Great flavors Crowd-pleaser Used Garofalo Penne Ziti Rigate (one ingredient) and cooked for 11 minutes instead of 8 minutes (al dente) and added fresh basil from the garden after baking.Otherwise, I followed the recipe asprinted.My son is a pasta snob — he loved it!! 07 of 780 Photo by  DapperDip7562 06/25/2024 Crowd-pleaser Amazing made for a wedding 08 of 780 Photo by  SappyThyme6603 03/09/2024 A keeper! Great flavors Easy to follow Worth the effort Crowd-pleaser The sour cream instead of ricotta added a nice touch, I'm actually lactose intolerant and I risked it all eating this delicious baked ziti. 09 of 780 Photo by  CheekyRoast6461 03/05/2024 Delicious! I tweaked it a little bit to my own liking, but the sour cream & provolone really brings this dish together . I haven’t tried it with ricotta, but maybe next time! I would definitely recommend mixing the noodles in the sauce then add it to the pan and layer everything . 10 of 780 Photo by  Alan Bartnik 02/18/2024 I add oregano, basil, and garlic but the base recipe is simple and delicious! 1 2 3 4 5 Next You’ll Also Love Easy Baked Ziti 1,213 Ratings Muffuletta Sandwich 70 Ratings Bento Box Turkey Roll-Ups with Caprese Salad Panzanella Panini 123 Ratings Reuben Sandwich 724 Ratings Cherry Cheesecake Brownies 24 Ratings Baked Chicken Empanadas Creepy Mini Pizzas 29 Ratings Ba'corn Cheese Corn 79 Ratings Bisquick Sausage Balls 194 Ratings Baked Brie with Caramelized Pears, Shallots and Thyme 44 Ratings Sugar Cookie Bars 16 Ratings Grilled Cheesy Garlic Bread Funeral Sandwiches 61 Ratings Crispy Fried Chicken 799 Ratings Sea Salt and Rosemary Pizza Bianca Bites with Mortadella and Mozzarella 1 Rating Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family.
